subject: RE: [junit] JUnit FAQ TestSetup example
msgSnippet: Thanks for your quick reply.  I should have named my class TestFixtureForPackage--is that a large enough comment?  ;) What I m trying to do is create one
messageBody:
Thanks for your quick reply. I should have named my class
TestFixtureForPackage--is that a large enough comment? ;)

What I'm trying to do is create one fixture that is reused for all my test
cases in the package I'm working on. I thought TestSetup would be the class
for this, but it seems like simply creating a parent TestCase class is the
way to go.

I was confusing the functionality of running setUp() once versus having a
reusable fixture.

Man does it feel late ...

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Chas Schley [mailto:chas@...]
> Sent: Friday, April 06, 2001 4:08 PM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [junit] JUnit FAQ TestSetup example
>
>
> Questions below, answers immediately following, rest of
> original message
> appended.
>
> > (1) Is there a better way?
> > (2) Will the variables defined in oneTimeSetup be in scope
> inside MyTest?
> > (3) How can I reuse the fixture defined in this class for
> another set of
> > tests?
> > (4) Will the fixtures defined the suite's TestCase's still
> be created?
>
> 1) Yes, comment your code ;) Seriously, a better way to
> what? What is it
> that you seek to accomplish? If, as the name AllTests
> implies, this test is
> simply plumbing to run all of your tests, then you don't need
> a fixture.
> You can remove the TestSuite wrapper and the oneTimeSetUp and
> oneTimeTearDown methods. Simply have your suite() method return the
> TestSuite to which you have added your tests, not the
> TestSetup wrapper.
> 2) Variables declared in a method are scoped to that method,
> so they are out
> of scope outside of the method. Class that inherit from the
> class in which
> your (public or protected) method is defined have acces to
> the method (and
> therefore the effects of the variable), but the variable is
> still scoped to
> the method and not beyond.
> 3) If you remove the TestSetup wrapper, then you won't have a
> fixture to
> reuse in other classes. At my company, I created a zTestCase
> class that
> extends TestCase. In my class, I define a generic fixture,
> and provide
> convenience methods for manipulating that fixture. All of
> our tests (all
> those that need the fixture) extend zTestCase. That way, our
> tests leverage
> the fixture in their supers, and override oneTimeSetUp if
> they need to alter
> the generic fixture.
> 4) Yes, unless their oneTimeSetUp overrides the setUp method,
> in which case,
> no. Again, it depends on what you seek to accomplish.
>
> Hope that helps,
>
> _chas_
>
> > From: "Mark Bucciarelli" <mbucciarelli@...>
> > To: <junit@yahoogroups.com>

>
> > I also found the FAQ confusing on this point. I'm sure
> it's my ignorance
> of
> > Java that causes me not to follow your helpful reply.
> Here's a class (and
> a
> > few questions below):
> >
> > public class AllTests extends TestCase
> > {
> > public AllTests(String name) { super(name); }
> >
> > public static Test suite()
> > {
> > TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();
> > suite.add(MyTest.suite());
> > suite.add(MyOtherTest.suite());
> > TestSetup wrapper= new TestSetup(suite)
> >
>
> > public void setUp()
> >
>
> > oneTimeSetUp();
> > }
> > public void tearDown()
> >
>
> > oneTimeTearDown();
> > }
> > };
> > return wrapper;
> > }
> >
> > public void oneTimeSetup()
> > {
> > }
> >
> > public void oneTimeTearDown()
> > {
> > }
> >
> > }
